item.title: Data from Critical thermal limits affected differently by developmental and adult thermal fluctuations
item.description: Sources Background Reproducibility key Caveats Reproducibility Table 1 (Results of ANOVA for effects on CTmin and CTmax of ±4 and ±8°C amplitude fluctuation after developmental acclimation (Fig. 2A)) Table 2 results Table 3 results Post-publication review Sources Salachan PV, Sørensen JG (2017) Critical thermal limits affected differently by developmental and adult thermal fluctuations. Journal of Experimental Biology 220(23): 4471-4478. https://doi.org/10.1242/jeb.165308 Salachan PV, Sørensen JG (2017) Data from: Critical thermal limits affected differently by developmental and adult thermal fluctuations.

item.title: Data from The interaction between predation risk and food ration on behavior and morphology of Eurasian perch

Ecology and Evolution 7(20): 8567-8577. https://doi.org/10.1002/ece3.3330 Svanback R, Zha Y, Brönmark C, Johansson F (2017) Data from: The interaction between predation risk and food ration on behavior and morphology of Eurasian perch.

item.title: Data from Ontogenetic thermal tolerance and performance of ectotherms at variable temperatures
item.description: Sources Background Reproducibility key Caveats Summary of Re-analysis Reproducibility Post-publication review Reproducibility Table 1 Table 2 Table 3 Figure 2 Post-publication review Use the full model to compare to Huey & Kinsolver Table of contrasts needed for interpretation Harrell Plots of full model ignoring sex Summary of my Harrell Plots and Table of contrasts Shift in UTL Red Flags Statistical misconceptions Sources Cavieres G, Bogdanovich JM, Bozinovic F (2016) Ontogenetic thermal tolerance and performance of ectotherms at variable temperatures.

item.title: Data from: Success despite the stress -- violet-green swallows increase glucocorticoids and maintain reproductive output despite experimental increases in flight costs
item.description: Sources Background Reproducibility key Caveats Data Reproducibility Initial measures Change in Cort Change in Body Mass Post-publication review “no significant differences” among treatment groups at baseline does not protect in any way against the bias in change scores (post - pre treatment measure) Estimates of treatment effects on Cortisol and Mass were not adjusted for baseline values Simulation to explore behavior in lmm vs. ANCOVA-lm vs. cLDA Adjustment for baseline comparing \(Cort_b\) Sources Rivers JW, Newberry GN, Schwarz CJ, Ardia DR (2017) Success despite the stress: violet-green swallows increase glucocorticoids and maintain reproductive output despite experimental increases in flight costs.

item.title: Data from: Density triggers maternal hormones that increase adaptive offspring growth in a wild mammal
item.description: Sources Background Reproducibility key Caveats Reproducibility Effect of spruce cone availability on local density (Fig. 1B) Effect of Density on growth rate (Fig. 2/Table S2) Effect of Density on fecal cortisol metabolites (Fig. 3/Table S4) Effect of FCM on offspring growth rate (Table S5) Effect of experiment Cortisol on growth rate (Table S6) Red flags Effect of Density on growth rate (Fig. 2/Table S2) Growth rate is a change score and is confounding by the basline Figure 2 doesn’t make sense Effect of Density on fecal cortisol metabolites (Fig.
